aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident in Independence, Iowa
The accident occurred in Independence, Iowa.
The accident occurred on April 23, 2020, at 09:25 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Vans RV 3.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN20CA155.
The aircraft registration was N24DE.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were no injuries to the single occupant.
The pilot practiced taxiing the airplane for about 1/2 hour.
The pilot attempted a takeoff and landing after practicing taxiing.
After landing, the pilot decided to practice a runway "speed up and down".
The pilot wanted to become more comfortable with engine settings.
During the first "runup," the pilot applied "very light throttle input".
The engine power increased "very fast" despite the light throttle input.
The airplane suddenly turned left.
The left wing dropped close to the ground.
The airplane was traveling between about 35 and 40 mph when the wing dropped.
The pilot applied right rudder to regain control.
The pilot changed the engine power to regain control.
The pilot was unable to gain control of the airplane.
The airplane veered left off the runway.
The airplane went up an incline after veering off the runway.
The airplane struck the airport perimeter fence.
The airplane impacted terrain.
The airplane sustained substantial damage to both wings.
A quartering tailwind prevailed at the time of the accident.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's failure to maintain directional control during a high-speed taxi with a quartering tailwind.
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control resulted in a runway excursion.
The runway excursion resulted in impact with a fence and terrain.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Independence, Iowa

## Date & Time: 
April 23, 2020, 09:25 Local

## Aircraft:
Vans RV 3

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN20CA155

## Registration:
N24DE

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The pilot practiced taxiing the airplane for about 1/2 hour before he attempted a takeoff and landing. After landing, he decided to practice a runway "speed up and down" to become more comfortable with engine settings. During the first "runup," he applied "very light throttle input," but the engine power increased "very fast." The airplane suddenly turned left, and the left wing dropped close to the ground with the airplane between about 35 and 40 mph. The pilot applied right rudder and changed the engine power but was unable to gain control of the airplane. The airplane veered left off the runway, went up an incline, struck the airport perimeter fence, and impacted terrain. The airplane sustained substantial damage to both wings. A quartering tailwind prevailed at the time of the accident.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during a high-speed taxi with a quartering tailwind, which resulted in a runway excursion and impact with a fence and terrain.

---
